questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with gradual onset edema and heavy proteinuria. Biopsy shows segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis. He has a history of heroin use. Which glomerular disease is most likely?
A 28-year-old smoker develops gangrene in the toes and migratory superficial vein thromboses. Histology of the affected artery would show which feature?

options.label: C
options.text: Microabscesses in thrombus with neutrophil infiltration

questions.correct_answer: C. Microabscesses in thrombus with neutrophil infiltration
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Microabscesses in thrombus with neutrophil infiltration

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy develops periorbital swelling and dark-colored urine 1 week after a skin infection. Which feature best differentiates PSGN from IgA nephropathy?
Match the following cardiomyopathies with their characteristic histopathological findings
Which finding would most reliably predict a worse prognosis in a child with PSGN?
questions.correct_answer: B. Extensive crescent formation on biopsy

questions.text: Which feature would most strongly argue against a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa?

Which of the following is not true about adenocarcinoma of the lung? 1. Common mutation is EGFR / ALK mutation 2. p40 positivity is seen in immunohistochemistry 3. Radiological finding is a peripheral mass with ground glass opacity 4. Stronger association with smoking in comparison to squamous cell cancer

A 4-year-old boy presents with 6 days of high-grade fever unresponsive to antipyretics. On examination, he has bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate, fissured lips, a "strawberry tongue," edema of hands and feet, and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Laboratory findings show elevated ESR and CRP, thrombocytosis, and sterile pyuria. If present, which of the following findings would argue against the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Desquamation of the fingertips in the subacute phase

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fever, chills, productive cough, and consolidation on a chest X-ray. The sputum culture grows Streptococcus pneumoniae. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism responsible for his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic interstitial fibrosis leading to impaired gas exchange

options.label: B
options.text: Small airway inflammation and mucus secretion

options.label: C
options.text: Airway remodeling and smooth muscle hypertrophy

options.label: D
options.text: Alveolar airspace consolidation due to bacterial invasion

questions.correct_answer: D. Alveolar airspace consolidation due to bacterial invasion
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Alveolar airspace consolidation due to bacterial invasion

questions.text: A 48-year-old diabetic woman presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and urinary frequency. Urinalysis reveals pus cells, and imaging shows a mass in the urinary bladder. A biopsy reveals macrophages with intracytoplasmic inclusions, which stain positive with von Kossa stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old hypertensive male presents with acute chest pain. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF; the troponin I level rises to high levels within 6 hours. His CK-MB rises but not as significantly as troponin. Which of the following best explains the difference in the kinetics of troponin and CK-MB in diagnosing acute myocardial infarction (MI)?

options.label: A
options.text: Troponin has a shorter half-life and peaks earlier than CK-MB

options.label: B
options.text: Troponin remains elevated for a more extended period compared to CK-MB

options.label: C
options.text: CK-MB is more sensitive than troponin for diagnosing early infarction

options.label: D
options.text: Troponin is released only after irreversible myocardial damage, while CK-MB is released earlier

questions.correct_answer: B. Troponin remains elevated for a more extended period compared to CK-MB
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Troponin remains elevated for a more extended period compared to CK-MB

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome is found to have a thickened glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy and a "spike and dome" appearance on silver stain. Which antibody is typically implicated in the idiopathic form?

A 30-year-old woman presents with a solitary nodule in the thyroid, along with mild hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy reveals ground-glass nuclei and psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man is hospitalized with acute kidney injury 8 days after starting ceftriaxone for community-acquired pneumonia. He now reports mild flank pain and malaise but no dysuria or gross hematuria. Laboratory findings are elevated serum creatinine and urinalysis, showing positive leukocyte esterase test, numerous WBCs, WBC casts, eosinophils, and no dysmorphic RBCs. His renal biopsy showed interstitial edema and infiltration with lymphocytes and eosinophils, with glomeruli appearing normal. Which of the following best explains the urinary findings in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immune complex deposition in the glomerular basement membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Ischemic injury to proximal tubular cells

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed hypersensitivity reaction causing interstitial inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: Deposition of Tamm-Horsfall protein and heme pigment in tubules

questions.correct_answer: C. Delayed hypersensitivity reaction causing interstitial inflammation
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Delayed hypersensitivity reaction causing interstitial inflammation

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of recurrent streptococcal throat infections presents with mitral stenosis. Her echocardiogram shows thickened valve leaflets and fusion of the chordae tendineae. Which of the following immunological mechanisms is most responsible for developing rheumatic heart disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Molecular mimicry between Group A Streptococcus and cardiac tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Activation of CD8+ T cells against endothelial cells

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of tissue repair by TGF-beta

questions.correct_answer: B. Molecular mimicry between Group A Streptococcus and cardiac tissue
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Molecular mimicry between Group A Streptococcus and cardiac tissue

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with autoimmune hypothyroidism. Her immune system attacks her thyroid tissue. Which of the following mechanisms would not explain why this autoimmune response has occurred despite the presence of central tolerance?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of adverse selection of autoreactive T-cells in the thymus

options.label: B
options.text: Mutations in the AIRE gene leading to defective self-antigen presentation

options.label: D
options.text: Peripheral tolerance failure due to inadequate Treg function

questions.correct_answer: C. Molecular mimicry with infectious agents
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Molecular mimicry with infectious agents

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a marfanoid body habitus presents with recurrent headaches, palpitations, and mouth ulcers. A CT scan reveals bilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas. Genetic testing reveals a RET proto-oncogene mutation. Which of the following is characteristic of MEN 2B and not MEN 2A?

A 55-year-old man presents with syncope and is found to have a left atrial mass that is pedunculated and mobile on echocardiography. The mass is confirmed to be myxoma. What is the most important complication of this lesion?

A 30-year-old woman presents with neck pain, fever, and tender thyroid. Laboratory results show elevated ESR and low thyroid hormone levels (T3 and T4). The patient has a recent history of upper respiratory infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old woman with new onset headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication presents with a markedly elevated ESR (120 mm/hr). Temporal artery biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with giant cells. Given the clinical and histopathologic findings, what is this disease's most likely associated complication if left untreated?

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent blindness due to ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.correct_answer: B. Permanent blindness due to ischemic optic neuropathy
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Permanent blindness due to ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.text: A new diagnostic test known as liquid biopsy is being used to detect circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in cancer patients. Which of the following is a primary advantage of liquid biopsy over traditional tissue biopsy?

options.label: A
options.text: More invasive and painful than tissue biopsy

options.label: B
options.text: Requires larger amounts of tumor tissue for analysis

options.label: C
options.text: Can detect genetic mutations in tumors without the need for a surgical biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: Only useful in detecting solid tumors and not blood cancers

questions.correct_answer: C. Can detect genetic mutations in tumors without the need for a surgical biopsy
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Can detect genetic mutations in tumors without the need for a surgical biopsy

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a neck mass, hoarseness, and diarrhea. Serum calcitonin levels are markedly elevated. Genetic testing reveals a RET proto-oncogene mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis and the associated genetic condition? 1. Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) 2. Medullary thyroid cancer with elevated calcitonin levels 3. Medullary thyroid cancer associated with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis 4. Follicular thyroid cancer with calcitonin-producing metaplastic cells

A 58-year-old male presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. His serum lipid profile reveals increased LDL-C and decreased HDL-C. Which of the following molecular mechanisms best explains the atherosclerotic plaque formation in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidized LDL particles promote endothelial injury and foam cell formation

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated HDL-C activates endothelial NO synthase, leading to plaque regression

options.label: C
options.text: Excess triglycerides inhibit HDL metabolism, leading to plaque stabilization

options.label: D
options.text: Increased LDL-C binds to intimal smooth muscle cells, promoting fibrosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Oxidized LDL particles promote endothelial injury and foam cell formation
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Oxidized LDL particles promote endothelial injury and foam cell formation

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with frequent respiratory infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive. He was found to have absent peripheral B-cells and normal T-cells during immunophenotyping. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient with a family history of colorectal cancer undergoes genetic testing and is found to have a mutation in the APC gene. Which of the following molecular mechanisms is most directly affected by this mutation?

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of function in DNA mismatch repair

options.label: D
options.text: Inactivation of p53 tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents with recurrent respiratory tract infections, chronic sinusitis, and oral thrush. Serum immunoglobulin levels show elevated IgM but low IgG and IgA. Further genetic testing reveals a mutation in the CD40L gene. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this defect?

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired complement activation due to lack of C3 convertase

questions.correct_answer: C. Inability to generate memory B-cells
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Inability to generate memory B-cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old male smoker presents with shortness of breath, wheezing, and a history of early-onset emphysema. On further evaluation, his serum alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) level is low. Genetic testing reveals a Z allele mutation in the SERPINA1 gene. Which of the following mechanisms contributes to the pathogenesis of this disease? Deficiency of alpha-1 antitrypsin leads to unregulated activity of neutrophil elastase, causing lung tissue damage Mutant alpha-1 antitrypsin accumulates in hepatocytes, causing liver damage and cirrhosis Defective alpha-1 antitrypsin leads to increased activity of matrix metalloproteinases, promoting collagen degradation Inhibition of elastin synthesis in the lungs causes loss of lung elasticity and airway collapse
A 60-year-old man exposed to asbestos presents with dyspnea and pleural thickening. Histology shows psammoma bodies. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
A tumor biopsy reveals abundant mitoses and nuclear pleomorphism. Which of the following features would most strongly indicate malignancy over dysplasia?
A patient with xeroderma pigmentosum has a mutation in a DNA repair mechanism. Which type of DNA damage does this specifically affect?
Match the hallmark of cancer with the mechanism involved

A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presents with chronic cough, sputum production, and dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows dilated, thickened bronchial walls. Pulmonary function tests reveal an obstructive pattern. Which of the following is most commonly associated with bronchiectasis? 1. Cystic fibrosis due to defective chloride ion transport 2. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) caused by cigarette smoking 3. Influenza infection causing acute bronchitis 4. Post-tuberculosis scarring leading to bronchial dilatation
Match Inherited Cancer Syndrome with Mutation

A 34-year-old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. His liver function tests reveal an elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and a positive anti-nuclear antibody. Imaging shows beading of the intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts. Which of the following is the most likely finding in this patient? 1. Presence of a positive anti-smooth muscle antibody (ASMA) 2. Association with autoimmune hepatitis leading to cirrhosis 3. Increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal cancer 4. Histopathological finding of lymphocytic infiltration and bile duct destruction

A 45-year-old female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and flank pain. Imaging reveals a staghorn calculi in the renal pelvis. The most likely cause of her condition is: 1. Urinary tract infection with urease-producing organisms 2. Hypercalciuria and hyperoxaluria 3. Renal tubular acidosis (Type I) 4. Chronic dehydration leading to supersaturation of urine

A 40-year-old man with sepsis and pneumonia develops progressive dyspnea and hypoxemia despite receiving supplemental oxygen. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates with normal heart size. Which of the following is the most appropriate explanation for his condition? 1. Increased capillary permeability and leakage of proteins into the alveolar space 2. Decreased surfactant production leading to alveolar collapse 3. Airway obstruction leading to uneven ventilation and perfusion 4. Increased pulmonary blood flow leading to pulmonary edema

A 72-year-old woman presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty finding words, and getting lost in familiar places. MRI shows cortical atrophy, especially in the hippocampus and temporal lobes. Which of the following pathological features are most likely contributing to her condition? 1. Neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein 2. Extracellular beta-amyloid plaque deposition 3. Lewy body formation within neurons 4. Demyelination of subcortical white matter

A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss on the right side and imbalance while walking. MRI reveals a mass at the cerebellopontine angle. Histopathology of the tumor shows areas of high cellularity alternating with low cellularity, and Verocay bodies are seen. Which of the following findings are characteristic of this tumor? Antoni A and Antoni B areas S-100 positivity on immunohistochemistry Keratin positivity on immunohistochemistry Origin from oligodendrocytes

A 28-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass. Serum tumor markers show normal AFP levels. Testicular ultrasound shows a homogeneous, hypoechoic mass. Histology reveals large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei arranged in nests separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic infiltration. Which of the following findings are most characteristic of this tumor? Positive staining for placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels Presence of large cells with "fried-egg" appearance Poor response to radiotherapy

A 28-year-old woman presents with her second episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg. She has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy. Family history reveals that her father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 45. Laboratory studies show decreased activated protein C (APC) anticoagulant activity despite normal levels of protein C. Which of the following congenital conditions are most likely contributing to her hypercoagulable state?

A middle aged woman arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings?

A 33-year-old intravenous drug user presents with fever, chills, and shortness of breath. On examination, he has a new systolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following best describes the nature of the vegetations seen in this patient ? Composed of fibrin and immune complexes Rich in bacterial colonies Large, friable, and destructive Composed of cholesterol and lipid-laden macrophages
A 40-year-old African-American man presents with nephrotic syndrome. Biopsy shows focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis. Which condition is most likely associated?

A 28-year-old man presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and hypertension. Imaging reveals an adrenal mass. Urinary metanephrines are elevated, confirming the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. His family history is significant for multiple endocrine tumors. Genetic testing is planned. Which of the following genes are most likely implicated in this patient’s condition? RET proto-oncogene VHL tumor suppressor gene NF1 gene RB1 gene
Match the following syndromes with their most commonly associated mutated genes:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A-4, B-5, C-3, D-1, E-2

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. CSF examination reveals elevated opening pressure, increased protein, markedly decreased glucose, and a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most characteristic gross finding in the brain of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Thick exudates over the basal cisterns

options.label: D
options.text: Cherry red spots at the base of the brain

questions.correct_answer: A. Thick exudates over the basal cisterns
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Thick exudates over the basal cisterns

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Homer Wright rosettes are TRUE? They have a true central lumen. They are seen in neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma. They represent tumor cells arranged around neuropil (neurofibrillary material). They are characteristic of retinoblastoma.

A 30-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer undergoes genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the BRCA1 gene. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which this genetic defect increases the risk of cancer? BRCA1 is involved in DNA repair, particularly in fixing double-strand breaks. BRCA1 functions as an oncogene, promoting uncontrolled cell division. BRCA1 gene mutation increases the likelihood of chromosomal instability and impaired homologous recombination repair. BRCA1 mutations cause defective apoptosis pathways, leading to uncontrolled cell survival.

A 6-year-old child presents with severe sunburn after minimal sun exposure. On examination, she has multiple freckle-like spots, skin erosions, and a history of developing basal cell carcinomas at a young age. Further investigation reveals a defective ability to repair UV-induced DNA damage. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is most likely defective, and what is the associated genetic syndrome?
A patient suffered from severe chest pain and expired. Which of the following is the likely age of infarct from the image of the cardiac biopsy shown here?
